revision.comment: Robot - Moving category People assisting Jews during the Holocaust to [[:Category:People who rescued Jews during the Holocaust]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 September 24]].
revision.text:
[[File:Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus.jpeg|thumb|Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus]] '''Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus''' were an American couple known for rescuing 50 Jewish children prior to the beginning of [[World War II]].<ref name="Lipman">{{cite magazine|url=http://jewishweek.timesofisrael.com/the-unlikeliest-rescue-mission/|title=The Unlikeliest Rescue Mission|author=Steve Lipman|date=March 28, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus lived in the [[Fitler Square, Philadelphia|Fitler Square]] neighborhood of [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania.<ref name="Lipman" /><ref name="Time">{{cite magazine|url=http://time.com/3879630/50-children-an-american-couple-saves-kids-from-nazi-germany/|title=50 Children: An American Couple's Mission to Save Kids From the Third Reich|author=Ben Cosgrove|date=April 20, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref> Gilbert, educated at the [[University of Pennsylvania Law School]], was an attorney, partner of a law firm, and president of Philadelphia Records. He founded the Doyleston Legal Aid Society, was president of the Bucks County Mental Health Society, and a member of Eagleville Hospital. He also bred Guernsey cows.<ref name="GIlbert obit">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/172936840/?terms=Gilbert%2BEleanor%2BKraus |title=Gilbert J. Kraus, 77, Ex-Record Executive | author= |date=August 22, 1975 |newspaper= The Philadelphia Inquirer|page=19|accessdate=June 30, 2017|via=newspapers.com|subscription=yes}}</ref>
They sent their children to a Quaker school. Eleanor wrote about the mission that they undertook, but it was not published during her lifetime.<ref name="Lipman" /> Gilbert died in 1975 and Eleanor died in 1989.<ref name="Lipman" />
==Background== After Austria was annexed to [[Nazi Germany]] through the [[Anschluss]] in 1938, conditions became difficult for Jews and they lost their rights. Many people wanted to immigrate to the United States, but immigration policy was very restrictive due to the Depression and anti-Semitism.<ref name="NNJN">{{cite news|url=http://njjewishnews.com/article/17407/film-features-nj-survivors-rescued-as-kids#.WVVACFMrKRs|title=Film features NJ survivors rescued as kids|author=Debra Rubin|date=May 20, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref>{{efn|President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] had asked that the American immigration quotas be expanded after the Anschluss. There were about 95,000 people who immigrated to the United States by 1939, particularly spiking after [[Kristallnacht]] in November 1938. There were about 399,000 Jews who left Austria and Germany by that time.<ref name="JID" /> The problem was not getting out of Nazi Germany, though, the problem was that there were not enough safe havens to accept them.<ref name="JID">{{cite news|url=http://www.jewishideasdaily.com/6423/features/they-all-could-have-been-saved-2/?print |title=They All Could Have Been Saved | author=Lance J. Sussman |date=May 2, 2013 |website=Jewish Ideas Daily |accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref><ref name="NYT" /> There were also some Jewish community leaders who asked the Krauses not to perform the rescue mission for fear of an uprising of anti-semitism in America.<ref name="JID" />}} Since 1934, there were Jewish groups who tried, but failed in bringing Jewish children to the United States. They knew three Philadelphian Quaker men who went to Berlin in December 1938 on a rescue mission, but were unsuccessful.<ref name="Time" />
==Rescue mission== Gilbert developed a relationship with [[United States Assistant Secretary of State|Assistant Secretary of State]] [[George S. Messersmith]], who had served as general counsel in Berlin (1930–1934) and then in Vienna (1934–1937), to focus his efforts in Vienna to rescue the children. Gilbert thought, though, that the best effort would be to work through [[Berlin]] first to have visas that were issued but unused due to death, travel to other countries, or arrest released for the children.<ref name="Forward" /> After meeting with Louis Levine, who originally proposed the idea, and Kraus, Messersmith issued a memo to the American embassy consul general [[Raymond H. Geist]] and the State Department officials in charges of visas about the plan.<ref name="USHMM" />
Eleanor took on fundraising and finding families who would take in the children. B’rith Sholom held fundraisers for the rescue mission. They raised $150,000<ref name="Forward">{{cite magazine|url=http://forward.com/culture/173372/hbo-documentary-tells-story-of-kindertransport-tha/|title=HBO Documentary Tells Story of Kindertransport That Saved 50 Children|author=Dorothy Brown|date=March 22, 2013|magazine=[[The Forward]]|accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> and obtained 54 signed affidavits from families who said that they would support the children.<ref name="USHMM" />
With the support of [[B'rith Sholom]], they went to Nazi occupied Austria and rescued children between the ages of five and fourteen in Vienna before the outbreak of World War II, which required them working with Jewish leaders in their community who opposed the effort and American immigration policy that make the effort difficult.<ref name="Lipman" /><ref name="NNJN" /> Gilbert set sail for Europe in early April 1939, and although Eleanor had been warned by the State Department not to travel to Europe, she traveled to Europe after Gilbert wired her from Vienna that he needed her help.<ref name="Forward" /> Traveling with them was a German-speaking Jewish pediatrician, Dr. Robert Schless. In Vienna, they met with individuals in the Nazi bureaucracy and at embassies.<ref name="Lipman" /><ref name="NNJN" />
{{quote box|align=right|width=33%|To take a child from its mother seemed to be the lowest thing a human being could do. Yet it was as if we had drawn up in a lifeboat in a most turbulent sea. Every parent we met seemed to say: 'Here. Yes. Freely. Gladly. Take my child to a safer shore.'|Eleanor Kraus<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/08/arts/television/50-children-about-saving-jewish-children-on-hbo.html |title=50 Small Victories in a Time of Unbearable Loss | author=Neil Genzlinger |date=April 7, 2013 |website=The New York Times |accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref>}} Hundreds of parents and children showed up to apply to have the children selected for the rescue. The children selected, 25 girls and 25 boys, were the ones considered most resilient to be separated from their family, whom they might not see again.<ref name="Forward" />
The Krauses traveled by train from the Vienna. When the children said goodbye to their families at the railroad station they were told they could not wave goodbye, as it might be considered as the Nazi salute and could result in their arrest.<ref name="Forward" /> In Berlin, the group received 50 visas from Geist.<ref name="Forward" /> They met with the [[Gestapo]] to obtain the passports for the children.<ref name="USHMM" /><ref name="JNNC">{{cite news|url=http://www.jweekly.com/2013/04/05/film-recounts/|title=Film recounts heroic story of couple who saved 50 children|website=Jewish News of Northern California|author=Renee Ghert-Zand|date=April 5, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> They then traveled to Hamburg, where they set sail for New York aboard the ''S.S. President Harding''<ref name="Forward" /> and arrived on June 3, 1939.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/89491506/?terms=Gilbert%2BKraus |title=50 Jewish Refugee Tots Are Happy in New Home | author= |date=June 5, 1939 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |page=2|accessdate=June 30, 2017|via=newspapers.com|subscription=yes}}</ref>
The children were first brought to B'rith Sholom's summer camp in [[Collegeville, Pennsylvania]], which had a 25-bedroom house.<ref name="Time" /> They then went to live with relatives who lived in the United States or foster families. The Krauses wanted to make another mission, but after the war began they were unable to make another rescue.<ref name="Lipman" /> Related documents and photographs were donated to the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]].<ref name="USHMM">{{cite web|url=https://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/irn95751|title=Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus collection|website=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref>
==''50 Children''== Their story was made into the documentary ''[[50 Children: The Rescue Mission of Mr. and Mrs. Kraus]]'' (2013) by [[Steven Pressman]], the husband of their granddaughter [[Liz Perle]]. It premiered on [[Yom HaShoah]], Holocaust Remembrance Day. According to Pressman, they were "the single largest group of [Jewish] children" that were brought to the United States during the Holocaust in one group.<ref name="Lipman" />
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Married couples]] [[Category:Children in the Holocaust]] [[Category:People who rescued Jews during the Holocaust]] [[Category:People from Philadelphia]]

{{Infobox person |image=Guy André Boy at TED-X.jpg |caption=[[TEDx]] talk, USA, 2012 |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1952|05|25}} |birth_place=[[Toulouse]], [[Haute-Garonne]], [[France]] |alma_mater=[[Pierre and Marie Curie University of Paris,]]
[[École nationale supérieure de l'aéronautique et de l'espace|ISAE-SUPAERO University of Toulouse]] |known_for=Intelligent Assistant Systems, Cognitive Function Analysis, Group Elicitation Method, HCI-Aero conference series, The Orchestra Model |awards=Fellow of the Air and Space Academy; Senior Member of the Association for Computing Machinery }} '''Guy André Boy''' (born May 25, 1952) is a French and American Scientist and Engineer, Fellow of the Air and Space Academy. He was University Professor and Dean of the School of Human-Centered Design Innovation and Art at [[Florida Institute of Technology]] (FIT), which he created, from 2015 to 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.fit.edu/faculty/profiles/profile.php?value=528|title=Faculty and Staff Profiles|publisher=Florida Institute of Technology|accessdate=1 December 2014}} He was Senior Research Scientist at [[Florida Institute for Human and Machine Cognition]] (IHMC).{{cite web|url=http://www.ihmc.us/groups/gboy/ |title=Guy Boy |publisher=Florida Institute for Human & Machine Cognition |date= |accessdate=2 August 2014}} He was Chief Scientist for Human-Centered Design at [[Kennedy Space Center|NASA Kennedy Space Center]] (KSC) from 2010 to 2016. He is known for his work on intelligent assistance, cognitive function analysis, human-centered design (HCD), orchestration of life-critical systems and tangible interactive systems. ==Biography== Guy André Boy is a computer scientist, an aerospace and control engineer, as well as a cognitive scientist. He obtained his PhD in automation and systems design in 1980 at [[École nationale supérieure de l'aéronautique et de l'espace]] (ISAE-SUPAERO), and his [[habilitation|HDR]] (habilitation as research director) in Computer Science and Cognitive Science in 1992 at [[Pierre and Marie Curie University]] - Paris 6. His HDR thesis was titled Methods and Tools for Cognitive Human-Machine Interaction. His HDR Committee included Professors Joëlle Coutaz, Pierre Falzon, Jean-Gabriel Ganascia, Georges Duvaut, [[Brian R. Gaines]], Yves Kodratoff, and Marc Pelegrin. He also obtained a master's degree in cognitive psychology at the [[University of Toulouse]] in 1983. His work mainly focuses on cognition, aerospace systems and organizations since the late seventies sharing his time between academia and industry.{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=CxLvGWAAAAAJ&hl=en|title=Guy Andr Boy – Google Scholar Citations|publisher=Scholar.google.fr|accessdate=1 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Guy_Boy?ev=hdr_xprf|title=Guy André Boy|work=ResearchGate|accessdate=1 December 2014}} In the early eighties, he created and led the [[Cognitive ergonomics|Cognitive Ergonomics]] Group at [[Office national d'études et de recherches aérospatiales|ONERA]]. In the late eighties, he created and headed the Advanced Interaction Media Group at [[Ames Research Center|NASA Ames Research Center]], California. He was Founder and President of the European Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Engineering (EURISCO){{cite web|url=http://chi-toulouse.hosting.acm.org/index.php/top-acteurs/entreprises/26-eurisco|title=EURISCO – European Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Engineering|author=|publisher=Chi-toulouse.hosting.acm.org|accessdate=1 December 2014}} in France – a research institute of [[Airbus]] and [[Thales Group]]. He led EURISCO from its creation in 1992 until its closing in 2008. EURISCO was a multidisciplinary organization made up of cognitive and social scientists, computer scientists, engineers and human factors specialists. It served students from various universities and engineering schools that were part of EURISCO's network of excellence. EURISCO focused strongly on its associations with the European aeronautical industry, research and education. In 2004, Guy André Boy co-founded the French Cognitive Engineering School ENSC: École Nationale Supérieure de Cognitique in Bordeaux, France. He taught cognitive engineering and human-centered design in several universities including FIT, École Polytechnique{{cite web|url=http://www.polytechnique.edu/jsp/accueil.jsp?CODE=36392593&LANGUE=1|title=Accueil – Ecole polytechnique|publisher=Polytechnique.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140926022431/http://www.polytechnique.edu/jsp/accueil.jsp?CODE=36392593&LANGUE=1|archivedate=26 September 2014|df=}} (Paris), ISAE-SUPAERO, [[Institut national des sciences appliquées de Toulouse|INSA]] and [[École nationale de l'aviation civile|ENAC]] (Toulouse), [[Paris Descartes University]], [[Civil Aviation University of China]] (Tianjin), [[University of Valenciennes and Hainaut-Cambresis|University of Valenciennes]], and ENSC. In 2008, he joined [[Florida Institute for Human and Machine Cognition|IHMC]] as a senior research scientist. In 2009, he became University Professor at [[Florida Institute of Technology|FIT]] where he created and directed HCDi,{{cite web|url=http://research.fit.edu/hcdi/|title=Human-Centered Design Institute|publisher=Research.fit.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} which supports the FIT HCD Ph.D. and Master's programs.{{cite web|url=http://research.fit.edu/hcdi/programs.php|title=Programs – Human-Centered Design Institute|publisher=Research.fit.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} In 2010, he was appointed Chief Scientist for HCD at NASA KSC (under an Intergovernmental Personal Act). He advised for several NASA projects including the Virtual Camera concept and tool for planetary exploration, which he created and developed, space robotics and the Glass Wall project for the renewal of launch control rooms. In 2013, he was nominated member of the Scientific Committee of European Commission's SESAR{{cite web|url=http://www.sesarju.eu/|title=SESAR – Partnering for smarter aviation|publisher=Sesarju.eu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} (Single European Sky Air Traffic Management) Joint Undertaking (SJU) Program, to provide advice to the SJU Executive Director, drafting of scientific opinions and provision of scientific advice.{{cite web|url=http://www.sesarju.eu/players/committee|title=Scientific Committee|publisher=Sesarju.eu|accessdate=1 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231064325/http://www.sesarju.eu/players/committee|archivedate=31 December 2013|df=}} Boy was inducted as a Fellow of the [[Air and Space Academy]] (Europe) in 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.academie-air-espace.com/mship/newdetail.php?varMbre=561|title=Air & Space Academy – Member Detail: Guy BOY|publisher=Air & Space Academy|accessdate=1 March 2015}} and a Senior Member of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://awards.acm.org/award_winners/boy_2738987.cfm|title=Guy Boy – Award Winner|publisher=ACM|accessdate=1 March 2015}} ==Work== Boy's early [[cognitive engineering]] research was on the first [[Glass cockpit]], conducted with Airbus and the French aviation authorities (1980–1984). He actively contributed to develop human-centered methods for cockpit design and certification of the first two crewmen cockpits. This early leadership in cognitive engineering led to an award from the French Ministry of Defense that supported part of his work at NASA Ames, where he developed an operation assistant system to enhance the control of the Orbital Refueling System of [[Space Shuttle]] (1984-1986). He coined the term "intelligent assistant systems" to denote systems that support human operators in safety-critical situations. After two years in France (1987–1988), where he co-founded a start-up company on intelligent assistant systems, Dialogics/Dialexis, he returned to NASA Ames to work on electronic documentation for the [[Space Station Freedom]] (1989–1991). During this period, influenced by [[Douglas Engelbart|Douglas Englebart]], who he worked with for a while, he developed an approach mixing hypertext and machine learning, leading to a system called Computer Integrated Documentation. This work led to a major publication on context-sensitive indexing. Back to France, he was nominated leading expert in Information Society and Technology for the [[European Commission]]. He served as an expert for the [[European Space Agency]] to establish the area of human-machine interaction and artificial intelligence (1991–1992). Creating and developing EURISCO, he became a legal expert for aircraft accident investigations (1992-1994). He then started new investigations in cockpit design and produced the Cognitive Function Analysis (CFA) method that was extensively used in industry for the design of safety-critical systems. Commercial aircraft cockpits became more computerized and generated more studies in human-computer interaction (HCI). He combined HCI and artificial Intelligence approaches not only in the aerospace domain, but also in education through the use of software agents. He also created the Group Elicitation Method (GEM) that is used for knowledge elicitation in HCD, and more specifically in [[participatory design]]. He helped in the restructuring of Air France at the highest level using GEM. GEM was used in many industrial settings, e.g., Airbus, Nokia, Daimler, Toyota Europe and in several European Integrated Projects funded by the European Commission. He collaborated to the Handbook of Human-Computer Interaction with a chapter in knowledge elicitation for the design of software agents. He wrote an introductory text under the auspices of [[UNESCO]] on theories of human cognition to better understand the co-adaptation of people and technology, in knowledge management, organizational intelligence and learning, and complexity. He coordinated the French Handbook of Cognitive Engineering: A Human-Computer Interaction and Cognition (Traité d'Ingénierie Cognitive: IHM et Cognition). He then contributed to develop the field of HCI in France, and was Co-Founder of AFIHM,{{cite web|url=http://www.afihm.org/association/320/conseil_d_administration.php|title=AFIHM – Association Francophone d'Interaction Homme-Machine|publisher=Afihm.org|accessdate=1 December 2014}} the French national equivalent of Association for Computing Machinery SIGCHI. He co-founded the first French [[ACM SIGCHI]] local chapter in Toulouse. He was the first French [[CHI (conference)|CHI]] paper Co-Chair (Inter-CHI 1993) with [[Jakob Nielsen (usability consultant)|Jakob Nielsen]],[http://www.sics.se/~jussi/Artiklar/Opublicerat/1993_rejected_InterCHI/ic93-papers-guide.txt] {{dead link|date=December 2014}} and was elected Executive Vice Chair of ACM SIGCHI (1995–1999), making him the first European ACM SIGCHI top executive.{{cite web|url=http://old.sigchi.org/bulletin/1996.1/chairs.html|title=SIGCHI Bulletin Vol.28 No.1, January 1996: 50 Years ACM, 14 Years SIGCHI|publisher=Old.sigchi.org|accessdate=1 December 2014}} This service to the HCI community, together with Richard Anderson, contributed to the creation of several local chapters worldwide. Within the human-computer interaction community, he collaborated with colleagues that were influential throughout his professional life, including [[Jeffrey Bradshaw|Jeff Bradshaw]], [[John M. Carroll (information scientist)|John Carroll]], [[Jonathan Grudin]], [[Don Norman]], [[Terry Winograd]], among many others. In 2015, he was elected Co-Chair of the [[INCOSE]] Human-Systems Integration Working Group. He also founded the HCI-Aero (Human-Computer Interaction in Aerospace) conference series{{cite web|url=http://www.aaai.org/Library/HCI/hci-library.php|title=AAAI Digital Library — Human-Computer Interaction in Aeronautics Conference|publisher=Aaai.org|accessdate=1 December 2014}} in cooperation with ACM-SIGCHI, the International Ergonomics Association and the Air and Space Academy (Program Chair, 1998-2014).{{cite web|url=http://research.fit.edu/hci-aero/HCI-Aero2014/Home.html|title=Home|publisher=Research.fit.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} HCI-Aero conferences followed the Human-Machine Interaction and Artificial Intelligence in Aerospace conference series, also created by Boy (1986–1995). HCI-Aero conferences have become a major reference in the field of HCI in Aerospace (full papers are indexed in the ACM Digital Library). He also created the Technical Committee on Human-Factors and Ergonomics of the [[International Ergonomics Association]] (IEA), which he leads since 2008.{{cite web|url=http://iea.cc/about/technical.php?id=51c0603673556|title=Aerospace HFE – IEA Website|publisher=Iea.cc|accessdate=1 December 2014}} He scientifically led two main projects regarding safety and human-computer interaction in aeronautics: DIVA,{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/growth/aeronautics-days/pdf/posters/diva.pdf|format=PDF|title=DESIGN OF HUMAN / MACHINE INTERFACES (HMI) AND THEIR VALIDATION IN AERONAUTICS (DIVA)|publisher=Ec.europa.eu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} a European project that tried to understand aircrew's awareness of both aircraft internal states and external situations using cognitive function analysis (1998-2001); and PAUSA, a French national project on authority distribution in air traffic management that contributed to the emergence of the Orchestra model for socio-cognitive analysis of multi-agent life-critical systems (2006-2008). This model and the development of HCDi led to the publication of the book, Orchestrating Human-Centered Design where he promotes education and training of leaders who understand technology, organizations and people (the TOP model). This book presents a humanist approach to design, engineering and more globally education.{{cite web|url=http://cpe.wpi.edu/images/CPE-New/IncoseInsightVol16No02-2013Jul.pdf|format=PDF|title=A PUBLICATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL COUNCIL ON SYSTEMS ENGINEERING|publisher=Cpe.wpi.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} With Jen Narkevicius, he proposed a unification of HCD and systems engineering for a better definition of human-systems integration.{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-02812-5_12|title=Unifying Human Centered Design and Systems Engineering for Human Systems Integration |accessdate=1 December 2014|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-02812-5_12|journal=Complex Systems Design & Management|pages=151–162}} He extended this HCD research effort on safety-critical systems to nuclear power plant control and management with two of his Ph.D. students. His research work is globally summarized in the discussion on cognitive engineering he had with [[:fr:Jean Pinet|Jean Pinet]], a former Experimental Test Pilot of Concorde,{{cite web|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/lunar/constellation/roverConceptNF2008.pdf|format=PDF|title=Small Pressurized Rover Concept|publisher=1pi.usra.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} and his dedication to automation, aerospace and education. Influenced by the work of [http://web.media.mit.edu/~ishii/ Hiroshi Iishii], he proposed the shift from automation to tangible interactive objects.{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1367578814000029|title=From automation to tangible interactive objects|accessdate=1 December 2014|doi=10.1016/j.arcontrol.2014.03.001|volume=38|journal=Annual Reviews in Control|pages=1–11}} He has participated in NASA Blue Sky Study Groups for the "Small Pressurized Rover," {{cite web|url=http://media.ihmc.us/capturethefuture/video/videoLunarRover.php?img=Lunar%20Rover&label=How%20the%20%20Lunar%20Electric%20Rover%20will%20work|title=Human Exploration of the Solar System Lunar Rover, How the Lunar Electric Rover will work|publisher=Media.ihmc.us|accessdate=1 December 2014}} (later called the "Lunar Electric Rover"). In 2012, he was the director of the International Space University Space Studies Program FIT/NASA-KSC local organizing committee and the chair of the team project of "what space can contribute to global STEM education." {{cite web|url=http://www.isunet.edu/news-and-media-center-2/1281-from-stem-to-steam|title=From STEM to STEAM… – International Space University|author=ISU – International Space University|publisher=Isunet.edu|accessdate=1 December 2014}} The same year, he gave a TEDx talk on "Human-Centered Design: the STEAM Renaissance".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2pfhTdc7KYc&list=PLsRNoUx8w3rORoM3gpfHvsxpS_TZ4JA6r&index=12|title=The STEAM renaissance: Guy A. Boy at TEDxSugarLand|work=YouTube|accessdate=1 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://sciencecareers.sciencemag.org/career_magazine/previous_issues/articles/2012_11_09/science.opms.r1200126|title=European Regional Focus: On the Horizon|publisher=Sciencecareers.sciencemag.org|accessdate=1 December 2014}} He continues to work on risk taking and wrote an interdisciplinary book on the topic published by the Air and Space Academy.{{cite web|url=http://www.academie-air-espace.com/publi/newDetail.php?varID=180|title=Air & Space Academy – Publication: No.32 – Risktaking|publisher=Academie-air-espace.com|accessdate=1 December 2014}} ==Selected works== ;Books *Boy, Guy (2016). ''Tangible Interactive Systems.'' New York: Springer: {{ISBN|978-3-319-30269-0}}. *{{Cite book | title = Orchestrating Human-Centered Design | last = Boy | first = Guy | year = 2013 | publisher = Springer | location = New York | isbn = 978-1-4471-4338-3 }} *{{Cite book | title = Cognitive Function Analysis | last = Boy | first = Guy | year = 1998| publisher = Ablex | location = Stamford, Conn. | isbn = 978-1-5675-0376-0 }} *{{Cite book | title = Intelligent Assistant Systems (Knowledge-Based Systems) | last = Boy | first = Guy | year = 1991 | publisher = Academic Press | location = San Diego, Calif. | isbn = 978-0-1212-1245-2 }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boy, Guy Andre}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lycée Pierre-de-Fermat alumni]] [[Category:Supaéro alumni]] [[Category:Pierre and Marie Curie University alumni]] [[Category:Human–computer interaction researchers]] [[Category:Design researchers]] [[Category:Cognitive scientists]] [[Category:French aerospace engineers]] [[Category:Senior Members of the ACM]] [[Category:Florida Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:NASA people]]

{{Infobox mayor | NAME =Ilija Čarapić
Илија Чарапић | image= | order=1st [[Mayor of Belgrade]] | term_start=7 May 1839 | term_end= 27 May 1840 | predecessor= | successor=Miloš Bogićević | birth_date=1792 | birth_place= [[Beli Potok (Belgrade)|Beli Potok]], [[Serbia]] | death_date=1844 | death_place= | spouse=Stamenka Karađorđević | alma_mater= | religion=[[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox]] | party= }} '''Ilija Čarapić''' ({{Lang-sr-cyr|Илија Чарапић}}, {{IPA-sh|ǐlija t͡ʃǎrapit͡ɕ|pron}}), was the first [[Mayor of Belgrade]], Serbia. He was born in 1792 in [[Beli Potok (Belgrade)|Beli Potok]], near [[Avala]], and died in 1844.[http://www.staribeograd.com/tekstovi/iz-starog-beograda/lat/postanak-terazija.htm Old Belgrade] {{sr icon}} He was son of the Voyvode [[Vasa Čarapić]] and the [[brother-in-law]] of [[Karađorđe]], appointed as [[Voyvode]] or Duke of [[Grocka]] when he was only 18 years old after his uncle, Voyvode Tanasije Čarapić, who died in [[Prahovo]], near [[Negotin]]. [[Vojvoda]] Ilija Čarapić, with his wife Stamenka [[Karađorđević]] had no children. Ilija was the stepfather of Stamenka's daughter Jelena Ristić, whom he married to Đorđe Radojlović, the founder of [[House of Radojlović|Radojlović family]].[http://ojkrajino.com/knjige/zene%20srpskog%20ustanka.pdf ŽENE SRPSKOG USTANKA] {{sr icon}} ==See also== * [[Mayor of Belgrade]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{Succession box | before = ''post created'' | title = Mayor of Belgrade | years = 7 May 1839 – 27 May 1840 | after = [[Miloš Bogićević]] }} {{end}} {{BGMayor}} {{Serbian revolutionaries}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carapic, Ilija}} [[Category:1792 births]] [[Category:1844 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Serbian people]] [[Category:People of the First Serbian Uprising]] [[Category:People from Belgrade]] [[Category:Mayors of Belgrade]]

{{eastern name order|Gófitz Ilona ''and'' Gófitz Judit}} [[File:Hélène and Judith, siamese twins known as The Hungarian Sist Wellcome V0007345 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Judith and Helen of Szony]] '''Ilona''' and '''Judit Gófitz''' (Hungarian: ''Gófitz Ilona'' és ''Judit''; in contemporary publications: ''Helen'' and ''Judith of [[Szőny]]''),{{cite web |url=http://silver.drk.hu/hu/content/2013-aprilis |title=A szőnyi ikrek |date=July 15, 2013 |publisher=Református Kollégium Nagykönyvtára |last=Oláh |first=Róbert |language=hu}} also known as the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] Sisters, were [[conjoined twins]] from [[Szőny]], [[Hungary]] who lived from October 19, 1701 to February 8, 1723.{{cite journal |last=Van der Weiden |first1=Robin M. F. |title=Disclosure of an unknown portrait of the Hungarian conjoined twin sisters Helen and Judith (1701–23) |date=August 1, 2008 |journal=[[Journal of Medical Biography]] |volume=16 |issue=3 |pp=173-174 |doi=10.1258/jmb.2007.007039}} The sisters, who were [[pygopagus]] (joined at the pelvis),{{cite journal |last=Simpson |first=James V. |title=A Lecture On The Siamese And Other Viable United Twins. |journal=[[The British Medical Journal]] |volume=1 |issue=428 |year=1869 |pp=229–233 |jstor=25216259}} were examined by doctors and exhibited to curious crowds throughout Europe.{{cite web |url=https://mentalfloss.com/article/55329/10-stories-conjoined-twins |title=10 Stories of Conjoined Twins |work=[[Mental Floss]] |author=Miss Cellania |date=February 27, 2014 |accessdate=July 20, 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sideshowworld.com/81-SSPAlbumcover/CT-1/Hungarian/Sisters-Helen-Judith.html |title=The Hungarian Sisters, Helen and Judith |publisher=Sideshow World |accessdate=July 20, 2018}} At the age of 9, the pair retired to a [[convent]] in [[Presburg]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Kingdom of Hungary]] where they spent the rest of their lives.{{cite web |url=http://www.madamegilflurt.com/2014/10/helen-judith-conjoined-twins.html |title=A Tale of Conjoined Twins |publisher=A Covent Garden Gilflurt's Guide to Life |first=Catherine |last=Curzon |date=October 19, 2014}} They died within hours of each other. After seeing them in London, [[Alexander Pope]] wrote a poem about the sisters:{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PD0sDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT39 |title=Inseparable: The Original Siamese Twins and Their Rendezvous with American History |first=Yunte |last=Huang |publisher=[[Liveright Publishing]] |date=2018 |page=21 |isbn=9780871404473}}{{cite web |url=https://www.thehumanmarvels.com/the-hungarian-sisters/ |title=The Hungarian Sisters |publisher=The Human Marvels}}
Two sisters wonderful to behold, who have thus grown as one, That naught their bodies can divide, no power beneath the sun. The town of Szoenii gave them birth, hard by far-famed Komorn, Which noble fort may all the arts of Turkish sultans scorn. Lucina, woman's gentle friend, did Helen first receive; And Judith, when three hours had passed, her mother’s womb did leave. One urine passage serves for both; one anus, so they tell; The other parts their numbers keep, and serve their owners well. Their parents poor did send them forth, the world to travel through, That this great wonder of the age should not be hid from view. The inner parts concealed do lie hid from our eyes, alas! But all the body here you view erect in solid brass.

F. |last2=Clausberg |first2=Karl |year=2015 |title=The Conjoined Twin Sisters Helen and Judith (1701–1723) and Their Pictorial Impact in Later 18th-Century Science |journal=[[Twin Research and Human Genetics]] |volume=18 |issue=4 |pp=419-424 |doi=10.1017/thg.2015.40}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Helen And Judith Of Szony}} [[Category:Conjoined twins]] [[Category:1701 births]] [[Category:1723 deaths]] [[Category:Hungarian people]] [[Category:Twin people from Hungary]] {{Hungary-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox writer |image = John s hittell.jpg |caption = John Shertzer Hittell |name = John Shertzer Hittell |birth_date = 25 December 1825 |birth_place = [[Jonestown, Lebanon County, Pennsylvania]], USA |death_date = 8 March 1901 |death_place = [[San Francisco, California]], USA | alma_mater = [[Miami University]] | occupation = [[Author]], [[Historian]] |relatives = [[Theodore H. Hittell]] (brother) [[Carlos Hittell]] (nephew) |signature = John hittell signature.jpg }}
'''John Shertzer Hittell''' (J.S. Hittell, 25 December 1825 – 8 March 1901) was an American author, historian, and journalist of the [[United States]] during the [[Golden Age of Freethought|Golden Age of Free Thought]]. Hittell wrote on a wide variety of topics including [[history]], [[mining]], [[Christianity]], [[Pantheism]], [[phrenology]], [[morality]], and [[politics]]. He is best known for his works ''A History of The City of San Francisco and Incidentally of the State of California (1878)'' and ''The Evidences Against Christianity (1856)''.
== Life and career ==
=== Early life and education === John Hittell was born December 25, 1825 in Jonestown, Lebanon County, Pennsylvania to Catherine and Jacob Hittell. Both of his parents were German immigrants who moved to The United States of America before The American Revolution. His family moved to Hamilton, a town in Southwestern Ohio, in 1832.
His brother [[Theodore H. Hittell]] was an author and historian who met and wrote about the life of [[John "Grizzly" Adams]] in his book ''The Adventures of James Capen Adams, Mountaineer and Grizzly Bear Hunter of California''.
Starting in 1839, Hittell attended Miami University and learned Latin, Greek, French, Mathematics, Chemistry, and Rhetoric. He obtained a Masters of the Arts degree in 1843. After graduating, Hittell decided to go into Law and entered the office of John Woods, a leading attorney in Hamiltin. His studies were interrupted by dyspepsia and headaches which Hittell attempted to cure by long walks and working on a farm in Hake County, Indiana.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Hittell Autobiography|url=http://oac.cdlib.org/ark:/13030/kt4k4020qr/?order=4&brand=oac4}}</ref>
=== Gold mining ===
In the spring of 1849 during the excitement of the [[Gold Rush]] he left the bank of the Missouri River with a company of adventurers en route to California. They arrived at the Sacramento River on Sept. 19th. Hittell spent the winter of 1849 and 1850 at Reading's Diggings (Shasta County).
He would go on to write books on mining with Mining in the Pacific states of North America (1861) and Hittel on Gold Mines and Mining (1864) respectively.
=== Move to San Francisco and writings ===
In 1852, Hittell moved to San Francisco and in 1853 joined the editorial staff of the "Alta California", where he remained employed for the following 25 years. Hittell was the author of numerous books concerning California history, resources, and industries.
He became one of the editorial writers of the Alta California newspaper, a position which he held, though not continuously, for more than twenty-four years. He was known as a hard worker and careful student, as was soon recognized as an authority in matters relating to the industries and resources of the State. In 1862 he published a book called "The Resources of California," and the seventh edition of it appeared in 1879. "A History of San Francisco," from his pen, was issued in 1878. Her has written several other books, numbering at least half a dozen, and has contributed much to cyclopedias and magazines. His range of knowledge was wide, including familiarity with the literature and tongues of Germany, France, Spain, and Italy.<ref>{{cite web|title=A History and Biographical Cyclopaedia of Butler County Ohio, With Illustrations and Sketches of its Representative Men and Pioneers|url=http://www.usbiographies.org/ohio/bios/butler/hittelljs.txt|publisher=Western Biographical Publishing Company|date=1882}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
He has been credited with being among the group of people to name [[Lake Tahoe]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hart|first1=James D.|title=Companion to California|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=teJCPQtWfOMC&pg=PA268&lpg=PA268&dq=j.s.+hittell+tahoe&source=bl&ots=v0r9N5h0g1&sig=NF1RswfTJcCr7gXaF8bWaBqHyx4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5s_DdmZHWAhUpxlQKHcRACJ4Q6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=j.s.%20hittell%20tahoe&f=false}}</ref>
Hittell owned land on [[Mount Diablo]] in a location known as Deer Flat. In 1873 an entrepreneur known as J.S. Hall, who had owned and conducted the famous Summit and [[Tip-Top House]] in Washington, approached Hittell about building a hotel, and constructing a carriage road to the summit of Mount Diablo. The two failed to come to satisfactory terms, with Hall finding a new place for the construction.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE MOUNT DIABLO HOTEL ENTERPRISE|url=http://www.newspaperabstracts.com/link.php?id=76599}}</ref>
In 1867 Hittell filed a patent for a new Washing Machine which he described as "consisting of an upright paddle-wheel common wash-tub, and is much more expeditious than the Wash-board".<ref>{{cite web|title=Patent for new Washing Machine".|url=http://www.google.al/patents/US61067}}</ref>
=== Works of fiction === In 1878 Hittell wrote versions of famous stories, adding in his own characters and plot. These were Regolstein: A Comedy (1878), based on [[La Grande-Duchesse de Gérolstein]] and Tannwald: A Drama based on [[Goethe's Faust]] by [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]].
=== Translations of works by Carl Reichenbach === Hittell undertook the first English translations of two works by author [[Carl Reichenbach]]. These were Odic-Magnetic Letters and a section of the large work, The Sensitive Man and His Relation to Od, titled Somnambulism and Cramp.
== Religious views andwritings == Hittell was a known freethinker in the early [[Freethought]] movement as well as a [[Pantheist]] as described in his book ''A Plea for Patheism''. Of his more well known books is ''The Evidences Against Christianity''.
Upon hearing that Hittell was to write a series of lectures against Christianity, famed early leader of the [[Latter Day Saint movement]] [[Parley P. Pratt]] sent him a letter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chapter 50 Autobiography of Parley Parker Pratt|url=http://www.gordonbanks.com/gordon/family/ppprattauto.htm}}</ref> {{Quote|text=MR. J.S. HITTELL. Sir--What do you mean by the term "Christianity?" If you mean the system taught by Christ and His Apostles, as recorded in the "New Testament," you need give yourself or the public no uneasiness, for no such system has troubled the earth for the last thousand years at least, so far as we have any knowledge, except in the single instance of its restoration in the United States by the Prophet Joseph Smith; and even this has been misnamed "Mormonism", and driven to the mountains of Utah.
In short, this Christianity of the New Testament is a system of visions, angels, revelations, prophesyings, gifts, miracles, etc. Such system you can never oppose--it speaks and acts for itself; its votaries know what they experience, see, hear and feel.
As to the modern systems--the forms without power, they are not worth opposing; they are dying of themselves before the power and intelligence of truth made manifest by "Mormonism."
I am happy to subscribe myself
The friend of truth and man, PARLEY P. PRATT}}
They appeared to be good friends with Pratt mentioning in reply to one Rev. Mr. Briggs in which Pratt was defending his polygamy against attacks made by Briggs, states:
{{Quote|text=He takes Polygamy, adultery, theft and murder, and compounds them all together as crime! And then seems to infer that a man would steal, commit adultery, etc., simply from the fact that he has a house full of wives and children! And even my good friend the learned and candid Mr. Hittell, although very just in the main drift of his argument, the other evening seemed to recognize no very clear distinction between Polygamy and adultery, or between a man having his own wife, or robbing a neighbor of his wife.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chapter 51 Autobiography of Parley P. Pratt|url=http://www.boap.org/LDS/Early-Saints/PPPratt.html}}</ref>}}
== Works == *''The Evidences Against Christianity'' ([https://archive.org/details/evidencesagainst00hitt ''Volume 1''], [https://archive.org/details/evidencesagainst02hitt ''Volume 2''], 1856) *[https://archive.org/details/pleaforpantheism00hitt ''A Plea for Pantheism''] (1857) *''A New System of Phrenology'' (1857) *''A Brief Statement of the Moral and Legal Merits of the Claim Made by Jos Y'' (1857) *''Mining in the Pacific states of North America'' (1861) *''Hittel on Gold Mines and Mining'' (1864) *[https://archive.org/details/resourcesofcalif04hitt ''The Resources of California''] (1867) *''Yosemite: Its Wonders and Its Beauties'' (1868) *''The Resources of Vallejo'' (1869) *''All About California, and the Inducements to Settle There'' (1870) *''A Brief History of Culture'' (1875) *[https://archive.org/details/historyofcityof00hitt ''A History of The City of San Francisco and Incidentally of the State of California''] (1878) *''Regolstein: A Comedy (1878) ''Translated and altered from the French text of the buffoon opera'', "The grand duchess of Gerolstein," by H. Meilhac and L. Halevy'' *''Tannwald: A Drama'' (1878) *''The Commerce and Industries of the Pacific Coast of North America'' (1882) *''St. Peter's Catechism'' (1883) *''Hittell's Hand-Book of Pacific Coast travel'' (1885) *''A Code of Morals'' (1888) *''Marshall's Gold Discovery'' (1893) *''A History of the Mental Growth of Mankind in Ancient Times'' (1893) *''The Spirit of the Papacy'' (1895) *[https://archive.org/details/historyofmentalg00hitt ''A History of the Mental Growth of Mankind''] (1899) *[https://archive.org/details/reformorrevoluti00hittrich ''Reform or Revolution?''] (1900)
== Articles == *"The Apotheosis of Steam", in Popular Science Monthly Volume 9, August 1876 *"San Francisco” in The American Cyclopædia, 1879.
== References == <references />

revision.comment: /* Education */I corrected the mistake realted with tense
revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{infobox person |name = Kalicharan Brahma
कालिचरण ब्रह्म |birth_date= 18 April 1860 |birth_place = Kajigami, [[Assam]], India |death_date=8 May 1938 (aged 78) |death_place= Kajigami, [[Assam]], India |othername= Mech Gandhi, Gurudev |occupation=Social reformer |spouse= Khwmsri Brahma Uphasi Brahma |children = 7 (4 daughter, 3 Sons) |parents=Khoularam Mech (father) Randini Mech (mother) }} '''Kalicharan Brahma''' ({{lang-brx|कालिचरन ब्रह्म}} 1860–1938), originally Kalicharan Mech, was a 20th-century social and religious reformer of [[Bodo people|Bodo]] society. He joined a new religion called [[Brahmo Dharma]] / [[Brahmoism]] [[Adi Brahmo Samaj]] faction in Calcutta around 1906, and he is reverentially called ''Gurudev'' or ''Guru Brahma'' by Bodo people of lower plains of [[Assam]] along Brahmaputra river. Other great Assamese [[Brahmo]]s of the time include [[Gunabhiram Barua]] and [[Swarnalata Devi]] of the same faction, all of whom agitated against Colonialist Imperialism of any kind. The followers of this group are locally known as Brahmas in tribute to their religion and the holy river of which they are sons. He was the founder of Boro Satra Sanmilanni ([[All Bodo Students Union]]). ==Early life== Kalicharan was born on 18 April 1860, at [[Kajigaon]] village in [[Dhubri district]], [[Assam]] state of India. His father was Khoularam Mech and mother was Randini Mech. Khoularam was a timber merchant and one of the rich person of the those days, as Kalicharan grew up he became intelligent, honest and thoughtful."Kalicharan Brahma" https://listbodolist.wordpress.com/2016/12/27/kalicharan-brahma/ He became a great religious preacher of [[Brahma]] faith and brought over revolutionary changes in Bodo society by his continuous and sustained programme of reformation against the prevailing [[Bathou]] worship. All the educated and enlightened section of the Bodo community including [[Rup Nath Brahma]] lent their all-round efforts in his reformatory programme, religious propagation through spread of education and political activism."[http://www.bodoland.org/history3.htm Welcome to Bodoland - History] ==Education== His pre-primary education in his home with a private tutor Birnarayan Mech. Later he joint in Tipkai primary school. After passing the primary school he joined in Puthimari M. V. School. But when he got in class five his father was dead . Kalicharan had to come back to home although he did not want to give up the school.[https://ranchai.blogspot.in/2016/11/gurudev-kalicharan-brahma-and-his.html?m=1/ "Gurudev Kalicharan Brahma and His Philosophy- Ranchaigiri Brahma"] Retrieved 25 June 2017 ==Work== By the end of the 19th century and the early part of the 20th century, the Bodo Society was also suffering from religious, moral and political degradation. The young Kalicharan Brahma could perceive the deplorable condition of the Bodos who were"bogged down with evil social practices" due to which the other commitments despised them. The Bodos who were one of the original inhabitants of the [[Brahmaputra]] valley were going through an identity crisis like the other marginalised indigenous Assamese communities. They had developed an inferiority complex. They were rapidly relinquishing their customs and traditions. The Bodo Society was disintegrating with the increase in the number of conversion to other religions. Many educated and affluent Bodos had begun to see their traditional beliefs and customs as stumbling blocks to modernization and human achievement. Kalicharan realized that the Bodo Society would have to be reformed. "He was filled with anguish and regret to see that the Bodos, although being followers of the [[Bathou]] religion were so only on a very superficial level.They showed little inclination in obeying the principle or guidelines set down by the religion. The worship of many gods and goddesses, whose number were only on the increase, was a clear indication that the people had moved away from their faith." They had become addicted to [[Bodo: जौव|jou]], Rice beer and developed bad social habits. The various social evils were sapping the vitality of the Bodo Society. Kalicharan felt that the identity and unity of the people could be preserved only though a change in their Society and religion. In 1905, he came across the [[Sarnitya Kriya]] written by [[Mohini Mohan Chattopadhay]]. The book contained the teaching of [[Swami Sibnarayan Paramahansa]]. Kalicharan became convinced that the adoption of the Brahma religion would be able to guide the Bodos towards progress and development and put a stop to the religious conversions. Thus at the age of 39, he got ordained into the folds of [[Brahmaism]] by Swami Sibnarayan at his residence in [[Kolkata]]. He returned to his native village with a determination to spread the religion among the Bodos. According to [[Bidyasagar Narzary]] and [[Malabika Mitra]]'s [[Journey Towards Enlightenment]] " The basic ideology of Brahmaism on which the religion was based was that there was only one God. In Brahma religion this God is worshipped in the form of fire is of primordial importance". "Fire is Brahma and Brahma gives life to the entire Earth and all its beings. Brahma is Universal, endless and all encompassing. Where there is Brahma, there can be found Satya or Truth." ==Death== He was died on 8 May 1938 due to old age in his village at the age of 78. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brahma, Kalicharan}} [[Category:1860 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:People from Dhubri district]] [[Category:Bodo people]] [[Category:Brahmos]]

page.title: List of Socialist Party of Great Britain members
List of female explorers and travelers

revision.text:
[[File:BellK 218 Gertrude Bell in Iraq in 1909 age 41.jpg|thumb|The female explorer and traveller [[Gertrude Bell]] in [[Iraq]], 1909.]]
This is a list of women who explored or travelled the world in a pioneering way. The list may include women [[naturalists]], [[sailors]], [[Mountaineering|mountain climbers]], [[Sled dog|dog sledders]], [[Human swimming|swimmers]], [[Aviator|pilots]], and underwater explorers. Astronauts are not included here but in the [[list of female astronauts]].
<!-- ALPHABETICAL order by LAST NAME --> {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !Nationality !! Born !! Died !! Achievement/s |- |data-sort-value="Adams, Harriet" | [[Harriet Chalmers Adams]] |[[Americans|American]]|| 1875 || 1937 || Explored and photographed South America, Asia, South Pacific |- |data-sort-value="Aebi, Tania" | [[Tania Aebi]] |[[Americans|American]]|| 1966 || || Held the record as the youngest person and first American woman to sail solo around the world (with stops and assistance). |- |data-sort-value="Arduin, Dominick" | [[Dominick Arduin]] |French|| 1960 || 2004 || Disappeared on her attempt to become the first woman to ski alone to the North Pole |- |data-sort-value="Bailey, Florence Augusta Merriam" | [[Florence Augusta Merriam Bailey]] |American|| 1863 || 1948 || American ornithologist and nature writer, who conducted extensive field work in the American West |- |data-sort-value="Bancroft, Ann" | [[Ann Bancroft]] |American|| 1955 || || First woman to travel over the ice cap to the North and South Poles |- |data-sort-value="Baré, Jeanne" | [[Jeanne Baré]] |French|| 1740 || 1807 || First woman (disguised as a man) to [[Circumnavigation|circumnavigate]] the world |- |data-sort-value="Batten, Jean" | [[Jean Batten]] |New Zealander|| 1909 || 1982 || First person to fly between England and New Zealand solo - broke other records |- |[[Carol Beckwith]] |American |1945 | |Photographer, author, and filmmaker known for documenting the tribal cultures of Africa, most notably in partnership with Australian photographer Angela Fisher. |- |data-sort-value="Bell, Gertrude" | [[Gertrude Bell]] |English|| 1868 || 1926 || Explored and mapped [[Greater Syria]], [[Mesopotamia]], [[Asia Minor]], Arabia |- |data-sort-value="Bingham, Laura" | [[Laura Bingham]] |English|| 1992 || || Executed expedition to cross continent of [[South America]] with no money. |- |data-sort-value="Bird, Isabella" | [[Isabella Bird]] |English|| 1831 || 1904 || Explorer, writer and naturalist who travelled by herself through [[North America]], [[Hawaii]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[China]], [[Vietnam]], [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], [[India]], [[Persia]], [[Kurdistan]], [[Turkey]], and [[Morocco]]. |- |data-sort-value="Bird-Walton, Nancy"| [[Nancy Bird-Walton]] |Australian|| 1915 || 2009 || Australian aviation pioneer |- |data-sort-value="Bly, Nellie" | [[Nellie Bly]] |American|| 1864 || 1922 || Pioneering journalist who travelled around the world in 72 days, the first person to do so. |- |data-sort-value="Boyd, Louise Arner"| [[Louise Arner Boyd]] |American|| 1887 || 1972 || Explored Greenland and the Arctic |- |data-sort-value="Butcher, Susan" | [[Susan Butcher]] |American|| 1954 || 2006 || [[Mushing|Dog musher]] in Alaska |- |data-sort-value="Cabra, Berthe"|[[Berthe Cabra]] |Belgian||1864||1947|| Belgian traveller, first European woman to travel across central Africa from East to West. |- |data-sort-value="Caddick, Helen"|[[Helen Caddick]] |English||1845||1926|| English traveller, diarist and author, travelled extensively in the Americas, Middle and Far East.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.birmingham.gov.uk/info/50165/birmingham_connection/1581/helen_caddick_and_her_diaries/1|title=Helen Caddick and her diaries|first=Vikki|last=Rainbow|date=|website=www.birmingham.gov.uk}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="Canary , Martha" | [[Calamity Jane]] |American|| 1852 || 1903 || American frontierswoman and professional scout, known for her claim of being an acquaintance of [[Wild Bill Hickok]] and for fighting Indians. |- |data-sort-value="Chlumska, Renata" | [[Renata Chlumska]] |Czech and Swedish|| 1973 || || Climbed [[Mount Everest]], [[kayak]]ed and bicycled around [[Contiguous United States|lower 48 states of USA]] |- |data-sort-value="Chojnowska, Krystyna" | [[Krystyna Chojnowska-Liskiewicz]] |Polish|| 1936 || || First woman to sail solo around the world |- |data-sort-value="Cottee" | [[Kay Cottee]] |Australian|| 1954 || || First woman to sail solo, non-stop around the world |- |data-sort-value="Coudreau, Octavie" | [[Octavie Coudreau]] |French|| c.1870 || c.1910 || Early explorer and geographer of the Amazon region in [[Brazil]] and [[French Guiana]] |- |data-sort-value="Crocker, Aimée" | [[Aimée Crocker]] |American|| 1864 || 1941 || Heiress, writer spent a decade exploring the Far East in the 1890s. Toured the interior of Java and Borneo. |- |data-sort-value="Danenberg, Sophia" | [[Sophia Danenberg]] |American|| 1972 || || First black woman to reach summit of Mount Everest |- |data-sort-value="David, Alexandra" | [[Alexandra David-Néel]] |French|| 1868 || 1969 || Travelled to Tibet while closed to foreigners |- |data-sort-value="Davidson, Robyn" | [[Robyn Davidson]] |Australian|| 1950 || || 1700 mile camel trek from Alice Springs to the west coast of Australia |- |data-sort-value="Dekker, Laura" | [[Laura Dekker]] |Dutch, German, and New Zealander|| 1995 || || Youngest person to sail around world solo |- |data-sort-value="DePecol, Cassandra" | [[Cassandra DePecol]] |American|| 1989 | || Traveled to all sovereign nations on a trip from July 24, 2015, to February 2, 2017; she thus obtained the Guinness World Record for "Fastest Person (Female) to Travel to All Sovereign Nations" and is the first documented woman, fastest American, and youngest American to do such a trip.<ref>{{cite web|last=McNulty |first=Rose |url=http://www.mensfitness.com/life/travel/how-cassandra-depecol-became-first-woman-travel-every-country-planet-and-stayed-insanely |title=How Cassandra De Pecol became the first woman to travel every country on the planet—and stayed insanely fit |publisher=Mensfitness.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-14}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="Dickson, Eva" | [[Eva Dickson]] |Swedish|| 1905 || 1938 || Swedish explorer, [[Pilot (aeronautics)|aviator]], travel writer and [[Rallying|rally driver]]. The first woman to have crossed the [[Sahara]] by car. |- |data-sort-value="Drummond, Lady Hay"| [[Lady Hay Drummond-Hay]] |English|| 1895 || 1946 || First woman to circumnavigate the world by air (by [[Zeppelin]]) |- |data-sort-value="Durham, Edith" | [[Edith Durham]] |English|| 1863 || 1944 || Explored Albania and the Balkans |- |data-sort-value="Earhart, Amelia" | [[Amelia Earhart]] |American|| 1897 || 1937 || First woman to fly solo across Atlantic |- |data-sort-value="Eberhardt, Isabelle" | [[Isabelle Eberhardt]] |Swiss|| 1877 || 1904 || Swiss explorer and writer in Algeria, who converted to Islam and traveled freely dressed as a man. |- |data-sort-value="Ederle, Gertrude" | [[Gertrude Ederle]] |American|| 1905 || 2003 || First woman to swim English Channel |- |Angela Fisher |Australian |1947 | |Photographer, author, and artist documenting the tribal cultures and adornments of Africa, most notably in partnership with American photographer [[Carol Beckwith]]. Her books include [https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/447435.Africa_Adorned Africa Adorned]and 13 others in collaboration with Carol Beckwith. |- |data-sort-value="Gordon-Gallien, Enid" | [[Enid Gordon-Gallien]] |British|| || 1931|| Explored and mapped Kalambo Falls |- |data-sort-value="Hillary, Barbara" | [[Barbara Hillary (adventurer)|Barbara Hillary]] |American|| 1931 || || First [[African American]] woman to reach North Pole |- |data-sort-value="Johnson, Amy" | [[Amy Johnson]] |English|| 1903 || 1941 || Pioneering aviator who set long-distance flying records |- |data-sort-value="Johnson, Osa" | [[Osa Johnson]] |American|| 1894 || 1953 || Made films of and wrote books about travels in Africa, South Pacific, [[Borneo]] |- <!-- Bluelinks only - please write article first | [[Lois M. Jones]] || 1935 || 2000 || First woman to travel on ice to the South Pole </tr>--> |data-sort-value="Kaltenbrunner, Gerlinde" | [[Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner]] |Austrian | 1970 || || First woman to climb all fourteen [[eight-thousander]] mountains without [[supplementary oxygen]] |- |data-sort-value="Kingsley, Mary" | [[Mary Kingsley]] |English | 1862 || 1900 || [[Ethnography|Ethnographer]] and explorer of [[West Africa]] |- |[[Belinda Kirk]] |British |(unknown) | |Founder of [[Explorers Connect]]. Kirk has travelled across [[Africa]], [[Nicaragua]], and the Chinese [[Taklamakan Desert]]. She captained the first all-female rowing team to circumnavigate Britain non-stop. |- |data-sort-value="Knight Ness" | [[Ness Knight]] |South African | 1985 || || [[Explorer]] and first female in history to swim the [[Thames River]] from source to [[London]] in 2013. Completed a solo traverse of remote regions of Northern [[Namibia]] in 2016. |- |data-sort-value="Kopchovsky, Annie" | [[Annie "Londonderry" Kopchovsky]] |Latvian American | 1870 || 1947 || First woman to bicycle around the world |- |Polly Letofsky |American |1962 | |First woman to walk around the world. In 1999, Polly began her 5-year trek around the world, raising awareness for breast cancer by partnering with the Lion's Club. |- |data-sort-value="Mansfield, Charlotte" | [[Charlotte Mansfield]] |English | 1881 || 1936 || Wrote ''Via Rhodesia'' (1911) about her travels in Southern Africa |- |data-sort-value="Markham, Beryl" | [[Beryl Markham]] |English | 1902 || 1986 || British-born Kenyan aviator (one of the first bush pilots), adventurer, racehorse trainer and author. She was the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic from east to west. |- |data-sort-value="Meakin, Annette" | [[Annette Meakin]] |English | 1867 || 1959 || First Englishwoman to cross the Trans-Siberian Railway. Wrote about this in "The Ribbon of Iron".Travelled in Russian Turkestan and other parts of Russia. |- |data-sort-value="Mexia, Ynes" | [[Ynes Mexia]] |Mexican-American | 1870 || 1938 || Mexican botanist and explorer who started her career at age 55. Discovered one new genus ([[Mexianthus]]) and many new species of plants. |- |data-sort-value="Murphy, Dervla" | [[Dervla Murphy]] |Irish | 1931 || || Irish travel writer known for cycling alone through Europe, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan to India |- |data-sort-value="Marquis, Sarah" | [[Sarah Marquis]] |Swiss | 1972 || || Swiss adventurer and explorer who walked {{convert|10000|mi|km}} across Asia, Siberia and Australia |- |data-sort-value="North, Marianne" | [[Marianne North]] |English | 1830 || 1890 || Prolific English Victorian biologist and botanical artist |- |data-sort-value="Pfeiffer, Ida" | [[Ida Pfeiffer]] |Austrian | 1797 || 1858 || Travelled alone around the world in 1847, published books of her numerous travels |- |data-sort-value="Pinheiro, Anésia" | [[Anésia Pinheiro Machado]] |Brazilian | 1904 || 1999 || Second Brazilian licensed female pilot in Brazil |- |data-sort-value="Rice, Kate" | [[Kate Rice]] |Canadian | 1882 || 1963 || First woman prospector in Northern Canada, writer, and trapper well known for her dog sled abilities |- |data-sort-value="Rutkiewicz, Wanda" | [[Wanda Rutkiewicz]] |Polish | 1943 || 1992 || Polish mountain climber, the first woman to successfully summit K2 |- |data-sort-value="Salak, Kira" | [[Kira Salak]] |American | 1971 || || Travelled in Mali and Papua New Guinea |- |data-sort-value="Schwarzenbach, Annemarie" | [[Annemarie Schwarzenbach]] |Swiss | 1908 || 1942 || Journalist and photographer, travelled to Iran, Afghanistan, Africa |- |data-sort-value="Smeeton, Beryl" | [[Beryl Smeeton]] |English | 1905 || 1979 || Mountaineer, cruising sailor, overland traveller |- |data-sort-value="Smith Peck, Annie" | [[Annie Smith Peck]] |American | 1850 || 1935 || First person to climb Mount [[Huascarán|Nevado Huascarán]] in the [[Andes]] |- |data-sort-value="Stanhope, Hester" | [[Hester Stanhope]] |English | 1776 || 1839 || Conducted first modern archaeology in [[Holy Land]];
