David Gorcey becomes David Condon; Bennie Bartlett replaces Buddy Gorman |- | [[1952 in film|1952]] || ''[[Hold That Line]]'' || Gil Stratton, Jr. replaces Billy Benedict |- | [[1952 in film|1952]] || ''[[Here Come the Marines]]'' || Last film with Gil Stratton, Jr., who is not replaced |- | [[1952 in film|1952]] || ''[[Feudin' Fools]]'' || Gang becomes standardized: Leo Gorcey, Huntz Hall, David Condon, Bennie Bartlett |- | [[1952 in film|1952]] || ''[[No Holds Barred (1952 film)|No Holds Barred]]'' || |- | [[1953 in film|1953]] || ''[[Jalopy (film)|Jalopy]]'' || |- | [[1953 in film|1953]] || ''[[Loose in London]]'' || |- | [[1953 in film|1953]] || ''[[Clipped Wings (1953 film)|Clipped Wings]]'' || |- | [[1953 in film|1953]] || ''[[Private Eyes (1953 film)|Private Eyes]]'' || |- | [[1954 in film|1954]] || ''[[Paris Playboys]]'' || |- | [[1954 in film|1954]] || ''[[The Bowery Boys Meet the Monsters]]'' || |- | [[1954 in film|1954]] || ''[[Jungle Gents]]'' || |- | [[1955 in film|1955]] || ''[[Bowery to Bagdad]]'' || |- | [[1955 in film|1955]] || ''[[High Society (1955 film)|High Society]]'' || |- | [[1955 in film|1955]] || ''[[Spy Chasers]]'' || |- | [[1955 in film|1955]] || ''[[Jail Busters]]'' || |- | [[1956 in film|1956]] || ''[[Dig That Uranium]]'' || Last film with Bernard Gorcey; last film with Bennie Bartlett |- | [[1956 in film|1956]] || ''[[Crashing Las Vegas]]'' || Last film with Leo Gorcey; Jimmy Murphy replaces Bennie Bartlett; Doris Kemper replaces Bernard Gorcey |- | [[1956 in film|1956]] || ''[[Fighting Trouble]]'' || First film with Stanley Clements; Danny Welton replaces Jimmy Murphy; Queenie Smith replaces Doris Kemper |- | [[1956 in film|1956]] || ''[[Hot Shots (1956 film)|Hot Shots]]'' || Jimmy Murphy replaces Danny Welton |- | [[1957 in film|1957]] || ''[[Hold That Hypnotist]]'' || Huntz Hall, Stanley Clements, David Condon, Jimmy Murphy |- | [[1957 in film|1957]] || ''[[Spook Chasers]]'' || David Condon reverts to David Gorcey; first film with Eddie LeRoy; Percy Helton replaces Queenie Smith |- | [[1957 in film|1957]] || ''[[Looking for Danger]]'' || Last film with Jimmy Murphy; Dick Elliott replaces Percy Helton |- | [[1957 in film|1957]] || ''[[Up in Smoke (1957 film)|Up in Smoke]]'' || Huntz Hall, Stanley Clements, David Gorcey, Eddie LeRoy |- | [[1958 in film|1958]] || ''[[In the Money]]'' || Last film in the series. |} ==Home media== All 48 Bowery Boys films were released on DVD by Warner Brothers via their "made-to-order" Archive Collection label in four volumes, each consisting of 12 films on 4 recordable media discs, beginning November 20, 2012. Initial distribution was advertised by Warner as being traditionally replicated on "pressed disc" media in anticipation of high demand for these first Bowery Boy releases to be "remastered from the best available elements." ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name | id=0329832 | name=Leo Gorcey}} *{{IMDb name | id=0355653 | name=Huntz Hall}} *{{IMDb name | id=0217316 | name=Gabriel Dell}} *{{IMDb name | id=0429853 | name=Bobby Jordan}} *{{IMDb name | id=058778 | name=Benny Bartlett}} *{{IMDb name | id=0329828 | name=David Gorcey}} *{{IMDb name | id=0329827 | name=Bernard Gorcey}} *{{IMDb name | id=0166265 | name=Stanley Clements}} *{{IMDb name | id=0070827 | name=Billy Benedict}} *{{IMDb name | id=0614357 | name=Jimmy Murphy}} *{{IMDb name | id=0833645 | name=Gil Stratton, Jr.}} *{{IMDb name | id=0331048 | name=Buddy Gorman}} *{{IMDb name | id=0503744 | name=Eddie LeRoy}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=The Bowery Boys | years=1946–1958 | before=[[East Side Kids]]
1940–1945 | after=Disbandment}} {{s-end}} {{Dead End Kids}} {{Little Tough Guys}} {{East Side Kids}} {{The Bowery Boys}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bowery Boys}} [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1946]] [[Category:Film series introduced in 1946]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American film series]] [[Category:Comedy films by series]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Fictional characters from New York City]] [[Category:Comedians from New York City]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = This Is Sanlitun | image = | caption = | director = [[Róbert Ingi Douglas]] | producer = | writer = Róbert Ingi Douglas
[[Carlos Ottery]]
[[Christopher Loton]] | starring = Carlos Ottery | music = | cinematography = Matthew Zhao Zuxiang | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2013|9|10|TIFF|df=yes}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = China
Iceland
Ireland | language = English
Mandarin | budget = }} '''''This Is Sanlitun''''' is a 2013 [[comedy film]] directed by [[Róbert Ingi Douglas]] and starring Carlos Ottery. It is a co-production between China, Iceland and Ireland. It was screened in the Contemporary World Cinema section at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://tiff.net/filmsandschedules/festival/2013/thisissanlitun |archivedate=9 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009113539/http://tiff.net/filmsandschedules/festival/2013/thisissanlitun |title=This Is Sanlitun |accessdate=30 August 2013 |work=TIFF}}{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/toronto-adds-75-titles-to-2013-edition-james-franco-alex-gibney-hayao-miyazaki-sean-durkin-and-kevin-macdonald-among-them?page=2 |title=Toronto Adds 75+ Titles To 2013 Edition |accessdate=30 August 2013 |work=Indiewire}} ==Premise== The film is a [[mockumentary]] about Gary, a British man, arriving in [[Beijing]] to set up a business and reconnect with his ex-wife.{{cite web |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/this-is-sanlitun-expat-dreaming-in-beijing |title=This Is Sanlitun: Expat dreaming in Beijing |work=The Straits Times |date=14 May 2014 |author=John Lui }} ==Cast== * [[Carlos Ottery]] as Gary * [[Christopher Loton]] as Frank * [[Ai Wan]] as Lin * [[Cromwell Cheung]] as Wang Ke * [[David Kenneth Vaughan]] as Jonathan Taylor-Sharpe ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|2728286|This Is Sanlitun}} {{Róbert Ingi Douglas |state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:This Is Sanlitun}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:Chinese films]] [[Category:Chinese comedy films]] [[Category:Icelandic films]] [[Category:Irish films]] [[Category:Irish comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Mandarin-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Beijing]] [[Category:Mockumentary films]] [[Category:Expatriates]] {{2010s-comedy-film-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder |name=Thomas Jefferson Rusk |image name=ThomasJeffersonRusk.jpg |width=200px | office1 = [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore of the
United States Senate]] | term_start1 = March 14, 1857 | term_end1 = July 29, 1857 | predecessor1 = [[James M. Mason]] | successor1 = [[Benjamin Fitzpatrick]] | office2 = [[United States Senator]]
from [[Texas]] | term_start2 = February 21, 1846 | term_end2 = July 29, 1857 | preceded2 =''(none)'' | succeeded2 =[[James Pinckney Henderson|James P. Henderson]] | office3=Member of the [[Congress of the Republic of Texas|Republic of Texas House of Representatives]] from [[Nacogdoches County, Texas|Nacogdoches County]] |term_start3 = 1837 |term_end3=1838 |predecessor3=[[John Kirby Allen]] |successor3=[[David S. Kaufman]] |office4=1st Texas Secretary of War |term_start4=March 17, 1836 |term_end4=November 13, 1837 |predecessor4=''Position established'' |successor4=[[William S. Fisher (Texas)|William S. Fisher]] |birth_date={{birth date|1803|12|5}} |birth_place=[[Pendleton, South Carolina]], US |death_date={{death date and age|1857|7|29|1803|12|5}} |death_place=[[Nacogdoches, Texas]], US |spouse=Mary Frances "Polly" Cleveland Rusk |profession=Politician, lawyer, judge |religion= |footnotes= }} '''Thomas Jefferson Rusk''' (December 5, 1803{{spaced ndash}}July 29, 1857) was an early political and military leader of the [[Republic of Texas]], serving as its first [[Secretary of War]] as well as a general at the [[Battle of San Jacinto]]. He was later a US politician and served as a Senator from Texas from 1846 until his suicide. He served as the [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore]] of the [[United States Senate]] in 1857. == Early life == Rusk was born in [[Pendleton, South Carolina]], to John Rusk, a [[stonemason]], and Mary Sterritt Rusk. After being [[Admission to the bar in the United States|admitted]] to the [[Bar (law)|bar]] in 1825, Rusk began his law practice in [[Clarkesville, Georgia]]. In 1827, he married Mary F. (Polly) Cleveland, the daughter of [[General officer|General]] John Cleveland. Rusk became a business partner of his father-in-law after the marriage. He lived in the gold region of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and made sizable mining investments. In 1834, however, the managers of the company in which he had invested embezzled all the funds and fled to [[Mexican Texas]]. Rusk pursued them to [[Nacogdoches, Texas|Nacogdoches]], but never recovered the money. [[File:MFClevelandRusk.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Mary F. Cleveland Rusk]] == Texas Revolution == Rusk decided to stay in Texas and became a citizen of [[Mexico]] in 1835, applied for a headright in [[David G. Burnet]]'s colony, and sent for his family. After hearing Nacogdoches citizens denounce the despotism of Mexico, Rusk became involved in the independence movement. He organized volunteers from Nacogdoches and hastened to Gonzales, where his men joined [[Stephen F. Austin]]'s army in preventing the Mexicans from seizing their [[cannon]]. They proceeded to [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], but Rusk left the army before the [[Siege of Bexar]]. The provisional government named him [[inspector general]] of the army in the Nacogdoches District. As a delegate from Nacogdoches to the [[Convention of 1836]], Rusk not only signed the [[Texas Declaration of Independence]] but also chaired the committee to revise the constitution of the [[Republic of Texas]]. The ''ad interim'' government, installed on March 17, 1836, appointed Rusk as Secretary of War. When informed that [[Alamo Mission in San Antonio|the Alamo]] had fallen and the Mexican army was moving eastward, Rusk helped [[List of Presidents of the Republic of Texas|President]] David Burnet to move the government to [[Harrisburg, Houston, Texas|Harrisburg]]. After the Mexicans killed all [[James Fannin|James W. Fannin's]] Texan army at [[Goliad, Texas|Goliad]], Burnet sent Rusk with orders for General [[Sam Houston]] to make a stand against the enemy. Rusk participated with bravery in the defeat of [[Antonio López de Santa Anna|Santa Anna]] on April 21, 1836, in the [[Battle of San Jacinto]]. From May to October 1836, he served as commander-in-chief of the [[Army of the Republic of Texas]], with the rank of [[brigadier general]]. He followed the Mexican troops westward as they retired from Texas to be certain of their retreat beyond the [[Rio Grande]]. Then he conducted a military funeral for the troops killed at Goliad. {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 2em; margin-right: 1em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:25em; max-width: 30%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: center;" | The men of Texas deserved much credit, but more was due the women. Armed men facing a foe could not but be brave; but the women, with their little children around them, without means of defense or power to resist, faced danger and death with unflinching courage. |- | style="text-align: left;" | — Thomas Jefferson Rusk{{cite web|title=Texas Trifles| url=http://www.texastrifles.blogspot.com/2004_06_01_texastrifles_archive.html| accessdate=2007-11-24}} |} ==Republic of Texas== [[File:TJRusk.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Thomas Jefferson Rusk]] In the first regularly elected administration, President Houston appointed Rusk secretary of war, but after a few weeks, Rusk resigned to take care of pressing domestic problems. At the insistence of friends, however, he represented Nacogdoches in the Second Congress of the Republic (1837–1838). Rusk was a [[Freemasonry|Mason]]. He joined [http://www.milamlodge2.com/Homepage.htm Milam Lodge No. 40] (Later Milam Lodge #2) in Nacogdoches in 1837 and was a founding member of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130110190218/http://grandlodgeoftexas.org/ Grand Lodge of Texas], organized in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] on December 20, 1837. As chairman of the House Military Committee in 1837, he sponsored a [[militia]] bill that passed over Houston's veto, and Congress elected Rusk [[major general]] of the [[militia]]. In the summer of 1838, he commanded the Nacogdoches militia, which suppressed the Córdova Rebellion. In October, when Mexican agents were discovered among the [[Kickapoo people|Kickapoo Indians]], Rusk defeated those Indians and their Indian allies. He captured marauding [[Caddo]] Indians in November 1838 and risked an international incident when he invaded United States territory to return them to the Indian agent in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]. On December 12, 1838, the Texas Congress elected Rusk [[Chief Justice]] of the Republic's [[Supreme Court of the Republic of Texas|Supreme Court]]. He served until June 30, 1840, when he resigned to resume his law practice. Later he headed the [[bar (law)|bar]] of the Republic of Texas. He and [[James Pinckney Henderson|J. Pinckney Henderson]], later the first [[List of Texas Governors|governor of the state of Texas]], formed a law partnership in 1841. Early in 1843, Rusk was called upon once again to serve as a military commander. Concern over the lack of protection on the frontier caused Congress, in a joint ballot on January 16, 1843, to elect Rusk major general of the militia of the Republic of Texas. But he resigned in June when Houston obstructed his plans for aggressive warfare against Mexico. Rusk then turned his energies to establishing Nacogdoches University (operated 1845–1895).{{cite web |url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/kbn01 |title=NACOGDOCHES UNIVERSITY |author=Robert Bruce Blake |work=Handbook of Texas Online |publisher=[[Texas State Historical Association]] |date=2010-06-15 |accessdate=2015-10-28}} He served as [[vice president]] of the university when the charter was granted in 1845 and president in 1846. == State of Texas == [[File:Thomas Jefferson Rusk statue IMG 2966.JPG|200px|right|thumb|Statue of Thomas Jefferson Rusk at [[Rusk County, Texas|Rusk County]] Courthouse in [[Henderson, Texas]]]] Rusk supported Sam Houston and the growing movement to [[Texas annexation|annex Texas]] to the United States. He was president of the Republic's [[Texas annexation#Tyler's preemption of Texas annexation|Convention of 1845]], which accepted the annexation terms. The first Texas state legislature elected him and Houston to the [[United States Senate]] in February 1846. Rusk received the larger number of votes and the longer term of office. Rusk and Houston forgot past differences as they worked to settle the southwest boundary question in favor of Texas' claim to the Rio Grande. Rusk supported the position of US President [[James K. Polk]] on the necessity of the [[Mexican–American War|Mexican War]] and the acquisition of California. In the debate over the [[Compromise of 1850]], Rusk refused to endorse [[secession]], proposed by some in the caucus of Southern congressmen. He vigorously defended Texas' claims to the land used to create the [[New Mexico Territory]] in 1850, arguing for financial compensation for Texas. As an early advocate of a transcontinental railroad through Texas, Senator Rusk made speeches in the Senate and throughout Texas in support of a southern route. The [[Gadsden Purchase]] received his support. Rusk was in favor of the [[Kansas–Nebraska Act]]. President [[James Buchanan]] offered him the position of [[United States Postmaster General]] in 1857, but he turned it down. (Buchanan gave the post to [[Aaron V. Brown]]) While Rusk attended to duties in Washington, D.C., his wife died of [[tuberculosis]] on April 23, 1856. Five of their seven children were still living at the time. During a special session in March 1857, he was elected [[president pro tempore of the United States Senate]]. Missing his wife and ill from a [[tumor]] at the base of his neck, Rusk committed suicide by a self-inflicted gunshot wound on July 29, 1857. He was 53 years old.{{cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fru16 |title=Rusk, Thomas Jefferson |author=Priscilla Myers Benham |work=The Handbook of Texas Online |publisher=[[Texas State Historical Association]] |date=2015-08-18 |accessdate=2015-10-28}} == Legacy == * The State of Texas placed a monument at the graves of Rusk and his wife, Mary, in Oak Grove Cemetery in [[Nacogdoches, Texas]]. *[[Rusk County, Texas|Rusk County]] and the town of [[Rusk, Texas|Rusk]] were named in his honor. * Part of his homestead became the campus of [[Stephen F. Austin State University]]. == See also == *[[Timeline of the Texas Revolution]] *[[List of United States Congress members who died in office (1790–1899)]] == Notes == == References == {{CongBio|R000518}} *{{Handbook of Texas|id=fru16|name=Thomas Jefferson Rusk}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071017140115/http://tamu.edu/ccbn/dewitt/rusktj.htm Biography on Thomas Jefferson and Mary Cleveland Rusk] == External links == * {{Find a Grave|6258942}} * Sketch of [http://texashistory.unt.edu/widgets/pager.php?object_id=meta-pth-5828&recno=555&path=meta-pth-5828.tkl Thomas J. Rusk] at [http://texashistory.unt.edu/permalink/meta-pth-5828 ''A pictorial history of Texas, from the earliest visits of European adventurers, to A.D. 1879''], hosted by the [http://texashistory.unt.edu/ Portal to Texas History]. {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | title=Secretary of War of the [[Republic of Texas]] | before=''(none)'' | after=[[Mirabeau B. Lamar]] | years=17 March 1836 – April 1836 }} {{succession box | title=Secretary of War of the [[Republic of Texas]] | before=[[John Austin Wharton]] | after=[[Barnard E. Bee, Sr.]] | years=22 October 1836 – November 1837 }} {{s-legal}} {{succession box | title=Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the [[Republic of Texas]] | before=[[John Birdsall]] | after=[[John Hemphill (senator)|John Hemphill]] | years=13 December 1838 – 30 June 1840 }} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{U.S. Senator box |state=Texas |class=1 |before=''(none)'' |after=[[James Pinckney Henderson|J. Pinckney Henderson]] |alongside=[[Sam Houston]] |years=February 21, 1846 – July 29, 1857 }} {{s-hon}} {{succession box | title=[[President pro tempore of the United States Senate]] | before=[[James Murray Mason|James M. Mason]] | after=[[Benjamin Fitzpatrick]] | years=March 14, 1857 – July 29, 1857 }} {{s-end}} {{USSenTX}} {{USSenPresProTemp}} {{SenPOCSCommitteeChairmen}} {{TXRepublicSecWar}} {{Republic of Texas}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rusk, Thomas Jefferson}} [[Category:1803 births]] [[Category:1857 deaths]] [[Category:United States Senators from Texas]] [[Category:Texas lawyers]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) lawyers]] [[Category:Army of the Republic of Texas generals]] [[Category:People from Pendleton, South Carolina]] [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:American politicians who committed suicide]] [[Category:Jurists who committed suicide]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Texas]] [[Category:Texas Democrats]] [[Category:Democratic Party United States Senators]] [[Category:Republic of Texas politicians]] [[Category:Presidents pro tempore of the United States Senate]] [[Category:Chief Justices of the Republic of Texas Supreme Court]] [[Category:Male suicides]]

'''Valeria Vegh Weis''' is an Argentinean-German critical [[criminologist]], [[criminal attorney]], and university professor with expertise in criminal law, mental health law, and transitional justice.
== Biography ==
Vegh Weis was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina. She attended Escuela n° 9 Manuela Pedraza School and then high school at [[Colegio Nacional de Buenos Aires]].
Vegh Weis is a lawyer from [[University of Buenos Aires|Buenos Aires University Law School]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Những điều có lẽ chúng ta phải biết ơn Marx |url=https://www.bbc.com/vietnamese/world-43982212 |website=BBC News |date=4 May 2018}}</ref> She obtained her summa cum laude law degree from [[University of Buenos Aires|Buenos Aires University Law School]]. Later on, she pursued post-graduate studies in Criminal Law at Buenos Aires University School of Law<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derecho.uba.ar/academica/posgrados/carr_esp_derpenal.php|title=Información General de la Carrera de Especialización en Derecho Penal - Posgrado - Facultad de Derecho|website=Universidad de Buenos Aires }}</ref> and a Master in International Legal Studies at [[New York University]]. She also pursued a PhD in Law at the same university and defended her PhD thesis on a Marxist perspective of criminal selectivity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derecho.uba.ar/academica/posgrados/doc_tesis_defensas.php|title=Defensas de tesis - Posgrado - Facultad de Derecho|last=UBA|website=Universidad de Buenos Aires}}</ref>.
She is currently working as a Professor of Criminology at [[Buenos Aires University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derecho.uba.ar/academica/posgrados/carr_esp_derpenal_oferta.php|title=Ofertas de Cursos de la Carrera de Especialización en Derecho Penal - Posgrado - Facultad de Derecho|first=Facultad de Derecho -|last=UBA|website=Universidad de Buenos Aires}}</ref> and [[National University of Quilmes|Quilmes National University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unq.edu.ar/carreras/10-especializaci%25F3n-en-criminolog%25EDa.php|title=Universidad Nacional de Quilmes - carreras - Especialización en Criminología|website=Universidad Nacional de Quilmes}}</ref> while a research consultant for Professor [[Thane Rosenbaum]] at [[New York University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.nyu.edu/news/forum-on-law-culture-and-society|title=NYU Law welcomes Forum on Law, Culture & Society|website=NYU School of Law}}</ref> She has also been serving on the Argentinean Judiciary for more than ten years (2005 to today) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mpdefensa.gob.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4016:dg-47-12-designacion-proietti-en-la-dgapcyf-designacion-vegh-weis-en-la-sgddhh&catid=238:resoluciones-dg-ano-2012&Itemid=852|title=DG 47-12|website=Ministerio Público de la Defensa}}</ref> and has been recently appointed as Associate Personnel at the [[Inter-American Commission on Human Rights]].
She has published extensively in Spanish and English on [[criminal law]], [[criminology]], [[transitional justice]] and [[mental health law]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://revueperiode.net/author/valeria-veigh-weis/|title=Valeria Vegh Weis – Période|website=revueperiode.net|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.viejo.periodicojudicial.gov.ar/archivo/edicion29/online/informedeprens233.htm|title=Artículo|website=Periódico Judicial de la Provincia de San Luis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltribuno.info/difundieron-alcances-la-ley-salud-mental-n46136|title=Difundieron alcances de la Ley de Salud Mental|first=El|last=Tribuno|website=El Tribuno}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://uba.academia.edu/VVeghWeis|title=Valeria Vegh Weis {{!}} Universidad de Buenos Aires - Academia.edu|website=uba.academia.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
She received the [[National Scientific and Technical Research Council|CONICET]], [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] and [http://www.law.nyu.edu/global/hauser/hauserglobalscholars Hauser Global] Scholarships,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.nyu.edu/global/hauserglobalscholars/pasthauserscholars#AY1516|title=Past Hauser Global Scholars - NYU School of Law|website=NYU School of Law}}</ref> the International Law and Human Rights <ref>{{cite web|url=http://chrgj.org/congratulations-to-2016-international-law-and-human-rights-fellows/|title=Congratulations to 2016 International Law and Human Rights Fellows |website=CHRGJ}}</ref> and the Transitional Justice Fellowship,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chrgj.org/scholarship/student-scholarship-opportunities/transitional-justice-leadership-program/2015-2016-transitional-justice-scholars/|title=Document Center - NYU School of Law|website=CHRGJ}}</ref> among many others awards. She has been a Lecturer for the [[World Health Organization]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cursospaises.campusvirtualsp.org/pluginfile.php/23331/mod_resource/content/0/Caja_Inicial/Institucional_Autoridades_SM_30-8.pdf|title=Cursos Paises Campus Virtual|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> a Visiting Professor at [[Strathmore University]], a Post-Doctoral Visiting Researcher at [[Freie Universitat Berlin]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jura.fu-berlin.de/fachbereich/einrichtungen/strafrecht/lehrende/drenkhahnk/mitarbeiter/Gaeste/index.html|title=Freie Universitat Berlin Guest List|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and a Post-Doctoral Fellow at the [[Max Planck Institute|Max Planck Institute in Legal History]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rg.mpg.de/person/93952/2373|title=Home {{!}} Max Planck Institute for European Legal History|website=www.rg.mpg.de|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
== Books and chapters == === In English === * Vegh Weis, Valeria (2017). Marxism and Criminology. A History of Criminal Selectivity. Boston: [[Brill Publishers|Brill.]] {{ISBN|978-90-04-31956-1}}. The book has been released in paperback by [[Haymarket Books]] (2018) {{ISBN|9781608469307}}.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Altman|first=Suppa|last2=Manuel|first2=Juan|date=2017|title=Marxism and Criminology. A History of Criminal Selectivity|url=http://www.scielo.org.ar/scielo.php?script=sci_abstract&pid=S1853-17842017000100013&lng=es&nrm=iso&tlng=es|journal=Revista de historia del derecho|volume=|issue=53|pages=0–0|issn=1853-1784|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=DeKeseredy |first1=Walter S |title=Valeria Vegh Weis. Marxism and Criminology: A History of Criminal Selectivity |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1462474518769019?journalCode=puna& |website=Punishment & Society |pages=1462474518769019 |language=en |doi=10.1177/1462474518769019 |date=9 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lea |first1=John |title=Marxism and Criminology: A History of Criminal Selectivity. By Valeria Vegh Weis (Leiden: Brill (hdbk), 2017, €138, Chicago: Haymarket Books (pbck), 2018, 340pp. |url=https://academic.oup.com/bjc/article-abstract/58/4/1020/4951250 |website=The British Journal of Criminology |pages=1020–1022 |language=en |doi=10.1093/bjc/azy007 |date=21 March 2018}}</ref> The preface was written by [[University of Kent|Kent University]] Professor [[Roger Matthews (criminologist)|Roger Matthews]] and the foreword was authored by [[UC Berkeley]] Professor of Law [[Jonathan Simon]]. The book received the [[American Library Association]] [[Outstanding Academic Title]]s award in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |title=Choice Awards Brill Publications as “Outstanding Academic Titles” in 2017 |url=https://brill.com/newsitem/22/choice-awards-brill-publications-as-outstanding-academic-titles-in-2017 |publisher=Brill |language=en}}</ref> Art cover by Enzo Leone.
=== In Spanish === * Vegh Weis, Valeria (2014). "Las teorías de la pena desde el Marxismo" [The Theories of Punishment from A Marxist Perspective]. In Perez Alvarez, F. Moderno discurso penal y nuevas tecnologías: memorias (in Spanish). Ediciones Universidad de Salamanca. {{ISBN|978-84-9012-525-0}}. * Vegh Weis, Valeria (2011). "Probation y Ejecución Penal" [Probation and Sentencing]. In Corach, Irene. 15 Años de Probation en Argentina: Responsabilidad Jurídica y Responsabilidad Subjetiva (in Spanish). Buenos Aires: Koyatun. {{ISBN|978-987-25733-9-3}}.

{{About||the American general|William Hawley (general)|the English soccer player|Willie Hawley}}
[[File:Heelstone Ditch & Scroll Trench.jpg|thumb|Excavations near the Heelstone (''The Antiquaries Journal'', 1925)]] Lieutenant-Colonel '''William Hawley''' (1851–1941) was a British [[archaeologist]] who undertook pioneering [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavations]] at [[Stonehenge]].
==Military career== Hawley joined the [[Royal Engineers]] and was a [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] of the [[Portsmouth]] division of the Royal Engineers [[Militia (United Kingdom)|Militia]] when, in late March 1902, he was seconded for service in [[South Africa]] for the later stages of the [[Second Boer War]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=27424 |page=2423 |date=11 April 1902}}</ref>
==Old Sarum== Along with [[William Henry St John Hope]] and [[Duncan Hector Montgomerie]], Hawley participated in the first major excavations of the [[Old Sarum]] [[British hillforts|hillfort]] between 1909 and 1915. These digs were organized by the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]].<ref name=sched>{{NHLE|num=1015675 |desc=Old Sarum|year= 2014|accessdate= 3 January 2015}}</ref>
==Stonehenge==
Work at the Stonehenge prehistoric monument was carried out between 1919 and 1926, largely by Hawley alone, at times assisted by Robert Newall, a draughtsman from the Office of Works. The weather and the confusing [[stratigraphy]] of this site made work difficult, but Hawley was able to make numerous breakthroughs regarding the history of activity on the site.
The first task was the supervised righting of some of the fallen stones, late in 1919. Hawley dug out the foundations before the stones were replaced. Hawley was employed by the Office of Works, the antecedent of the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]] who had been passed responsibility for Stonehenge when it had been donated to the nation in 1918. They were primarily concerned with the danger of falling stones, but funds were made available for Hawley to continue his investigations long after the righting work was finished.
Hawley identified the [[Aubrey Holes]] for the first time, as well as the [[Y and Z Holes]] and a variety of other [[posthole]]s and stone holes within the centre of the monument. He found many of the cremated and uncremated human remains which first indicated a funerary role for Stonehenge. Excavations of the [[avenue (archaeology)|Avenue]], the ditch ([[Heelstone Ditch]]) around the [[Heelstone]], and the trench (Arc Trench) leading up to the Heelstone were also undertaken.
Hawley proved, from a thin stratum of stone chip debris he called the Stonehenge Layer, that the earthwork features, the Aubrey Holes and some of the other postholes and burials constituted earlier phases of activity that predated the erection of the megaliths. He also found an antler pick embedded in a lump of chalk, indicating the construction method on site. Eventually he settled on three phases: the earthwork enclosure, a large stone circle now vanished that supposedly stood in the Aubrey Holes, and finally a larger megaliths phase involving the extant stones as Stonehenge 3. Hawley's model of a multiphase site did not agree with the contemporary interpretation and was ignored until [[Richard J. C. Atkinson|Richard Atkinson]] revived the idea in the 1950s. Although later considerably refined, his multi-phase interpretation is now fully accepted.
Certain of Hawley's other ideas, such as Stonehenge being a fortified settlement, were further off the mark and he died before his work was recognised.
Artefacts excavated by Hawley at Stonehenge are displayed in the Wessex Gallery of Archaeology at the [[The Salisbury Museum|Salisbury Museum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/reviews/salisbury-museum.htm|title=Salisbury Museum|last=|first=|date=8 October 2014|website=Current archaeology|publisher=|language=en-GB|access-date=14 September 2016}}</ref> Selected samples were also sent to the [[Ashmolean Museum|Ashmolean]] (Oxford), the [[Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, University of Cambridge|Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]] (Cambridge), the [[National Museum Cardiff|National Museum of Wales]] (Cardiff), and the [[British Museum]] (London).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ashmolean.org/ash/faqs/q006/q006002.html|title=Ashmolean Museum; British Archaeology: Stonehenge and the Ashmolean|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ashmolean.org|publisher=|access-date=14 September 2016}}</ref>
